slides.title: EcAZ Phage Project Progress
slides.subtitle: Group Meeting Report
slides.notes:
Good morning/afternoon, everyone!

Today I'll be presenting the latest progress on our EcAZ phage project. The goal of this project is to isolate bacteriophages that can infect EcAZ E. coli strains from sewage samples.

I'll cover the project background, isolation results, host range determination, titer determination, and killing curve experiments.

slides.title: Project Background
content: Objective: Isolate phages infecting EcAZ E. coli from sewage
slides.notes:
Let me start with the project background.

Our core objective is to isolate bacteriophages capable of infecting EcAZ E. coli from sewage samples. Sewage is a natural reservoir of phage diversity.

We used two host strains: EcAZ-1, a wild-type strain we call W, and EcAZ-2-OVA, an engineered strain expressing OVA antigen, which we call R.

slides.title: Phage Isolation Results
slides.notes:
Through multiple rounds of enrichment and purification, we successfully isolated five bacteriophages.

R1, R2, and R3 were enriched using the R strain, while W1 and W2 were enriched using the W strain.

These five phages exhibit distinct plaque morphologies: R1 produces tiny plaques, R2 produces turbid plaques, and R3 produces large, clear plaques.

slides.title: Plaque Morphology Characteristics
slides.footnote: R2 is the only turbid plaque (possibly temperate); R3 has the largest plaques
slides.notes:
We characterized three parameters: diameter, clarity, and halo presence.

R1 is the smallest at 0.1-0.2mm, while R3 is the largest at 3.2mm—a 15-fold difference.

R2 is uniquely turbid, suggesting it might be a temperate phage.

All except R2 show halos, suggesting these phages may carry polysaccharide-degrading enzymes.

slides.title: Host Range Determination Results
slides.notes:
Host range determination revealed an important finding: R1 can only infect the R strain and completely fails to infect the W strain.

This is the only **narrow-host-range** phage among all five isolates!

One possible explanation is that the OVA protein expressed on the R strain's surface creates a unique receptor that R1 specifically recognizes.

slides.title: Titer Determination Results
slides.footnote: R2 and W2 have the highest titers at 10¹⁴ PFU/mL
slides.notes:
Titer determination shows significant variation among the five phages.

R2 and W2 have the highest titers, reaching 10^14 PFU/mL.

R1 and R3 have relatively lower titers, around 10^10 PFU/mL.

These data provide important references for subsequent experiments.

slides.title: Killing Curve: W Strain MOI Optimization
slides.footnote: W1: MOI=10 fastest; W2: MOI=1 most efficient
slides.notes:
We performed 12-hour continuous monitoring killing curve experiments using BioTek Epoch 2.

W1 phage at MOI=10 showed the fastest lysis, starting at just 56 minutes. All MOIs achieved effective killing.

W2 phage at MOI=1 showed the highest killing efficiency, though overall lysis was slightly slower than W1.

Recommended MOI: W1 use MOI≥1, W2 use MOI=1.

slides.title: Conclusions & Future Plans
findings: R2 produces **turbid plaques**, possibly temperate phage
W1/W2 killing curves: **W1 MOI=10 fastest, W2 MOI=1 strongest**
next_steps: R strain killing curve experiments (R1, R2, R3)
slides.notes:
Key findings summary:

First, we successfully isolated five bacteriophages. Second, R1 is the only narrow-host-range phage. Third, R2 may be a temperate phage. Fourth, optimal MOIs for W1 and W2 have been determined.

Next steps: Complete R strain killing curve experiments, then conduct one-step growth curves and genome sequencing.

Thank you all for your attention!

Questions and discussions are welcome. Thank you!
